choices.text: Both assertion and reason are false.
Assertion is true but reason is false.
Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is correct for assertion.
Assertion is false, reason is true.

questions.text:
Regarding the given instrument, choose the correct answer

Assertion: These blades are used in pediatric tracheal intubation.
Reason: The epiglottis in children are floppier, curved and longer than their adult counterparts.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image depicts a straight laryngoscope blade (Miller's blade), which directly lifts the epiglottis.
  • It is recommended for pediatric tracheal intubation as their epiglottis are floppier, curved, and longer than their adult counterparts, which can obscure the glottis if not lifted directly.
  • In adults, curved blades (e.g., Macintosh) are often used to indirectly lift the epiglottis by engaging the vallecula.

choices.text: Cervical spine movement in unstable injuries

questions.text: Complications associated with the use of face mask ventilation are all except
questions.solution:
Explantion:

  • Face mask ventilation involves no invasive airway device, so sore throat is minimal compared to supraglottic or endotracheal techniques.
  • Complications associated with facemask ventilation:
    • Gastric insufflation: (Option B)
      • Positive-pressure mask ventilation can force gas into the stomach.
      • Keeping inspiratory pressures below 20 cm H2O reduces this risk.
    • Cervical spine movement:
      • Mask manoeuvres (head-tilt/chin-lift or jaw-thrust) can produce more neck motion than some intubation techniques, risking harm in unstable injuries.
    • Environmental pollution:
      • Leaks around the mask release anaesthetic gases into the OR, increasing staff exposure compared to a tracheal tube or supraglottic airway device.
    • Inadequate seal
      • Leads to hypoventilation, hypercapnia or hypoxia if mask fit is poor like in patients with facial hair, obesity or edentulous gums.

choices.text: Seeing the tube pass through the vocal cords
Observing chest wall movement during inspiration and exhalation.
Hearing breath sounds during controlled ventilation

questions.text: A junior trainee has been assigned the task of intubating a young female patient posted for a laparoscopic appendectomy. Which is the single best method among the following to rule out oesophageal intubation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ASA Standards for Basic Anaesthetic Monitoring and AANA guidelines mandate that after tracheal intubation, tube placement must be confirmed by identification of CO2 in expired gas.
  • Continuous waveform capnography is the gold standard, providing real-time, objective verification of tracheal (vs. oesophagal) placement.

Systems Monitored by Capnography:

  1. Metabolism: CO2 production
  2. Circulation: CO2 transport to lungs
  3. Ventilation: CO2 elimination at the alveolar - airway interface

Uses of Capnography:

  1. ETT Confirmation: Differentiates tracheal vs. oesophageal intubation.
  2. CPR Monitoring:
    • Flat trace in arrest
    • EtCO2 > 20 mm Hg → effective compressions
    • Sudden rise → return of spontaneous circulation
  3. Ventilation Assessment:
    • Low, crowded waveform → hyperventilation
    • Elevated, prolonged waveform → hypoventilation
  4. Intra-operative Detection:
    • Malignant hyperthermia → sudden EtCO2 ↑ × 2-3
    • Air embolism → abrupt EtCO2 ↓
  • Subjective methods (visualising cords, chest rise, auscultation) can be misleading due to:
    • Gastric insufflation producing chest movement (Option B ruled out)
    • Transmitted breath sounds heard over the chest wall even with oesophageal intubation (Option C ruled out)
    • Partial oesophageal placement despite visual confirmation
    • Visualization does not guarantee continued correct position during manipulation. (Option A ruled out)

choices.text: Use of low volume, high pressure cuffs
Lubrication of tube with lidocaine jelly
Using a smaller sized endotracheal tube

questions.text: A 24-year-old female underwent a routine procedure under general anaesthesia with endotracheal intubation, after which she had a complaint of hoarseness of voice. Which among the following is not a measure to help reduce the incidence of post-extubation hoarseness?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

High-pressure cuffs exert focal pressure on the mucosa, increasing the risk of ischemia and hoarseness.

  • Measures that reduce hoarseness include:
    • Using low-pressure, high-volume cuffs to distribute pressure evenly
    • Lubricating the tube with lidocaine jelly to minimise friction (Option B)
    • Selecting a smaller endotracheal tube to reduce mucosal stretch (Option C)
    • Performing an atraumatic, gentle intubation technique (Option D)
  • Prolonged or difficult intubations further increase the risk of laryngeal oedema and vocal cord injury.
  • Persistent hoarseness beyond 72 hours warrants laryngoscopic evaluation to exclude vocal cord pathology.

questions.text: A first-year trainee in anaesthesia intubates a patient posted for an elective surgery. Which auscultator technique gives the most reliable indication that the tracheal tube is in the trachea?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Auscultation should be performed high in each midaxillary area, not just the anterior chest region.
  • The quality of the sounds is important.
  • A gurgling sound (death rattle) suggests oesophageal placement. This test is not always reliable.
  • Auscultating the upper abdomen as well as the lungs may increase the reliability of auscultation.
  • But these sounds may be confused with breath sounds that are often heard in the epigastric area in thin individuals and pediatric patients.

Explanation of other options:

  • Auscultation of the upper abdomen (Option A) may detect gastric air entry but not reliably distinguish tracheal placement.
  • Gurgling sounds with ventilation (Option B) indicate oesophagal intubation; not a positive sign for correct placement.
  • Airway auscultation (Option C): Breath sounds over the anterior neck or trachea can be confused with transmitted or ambient noises.

choices.text: Achieving a seal in edentulous patients is difficult
Volume within the mask is dead space

questions.text: You are using a sealing face mask to oxygenate a patient. All of the following are the disadvantages of sealing face masks except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A sealing face mask with a soft cushion can deliver high-flow oxygen and, with an appropriate breathing system, achieve nearly 100% FiO2.

  • Face mask have a soft seal that fits over the patient's nose and mouth.
  • Achieving a seal may prove difficult in some patients, particularly the edentulous, as they lack the facial structure to support the mask seal. (Option A)
  • The volume within the mask is dead space. (Option B)
  • Paediatric masks are smaller and are often used without a catheter mount to offset this.
  • Claustrophobia is a significant problem in some patients. (Option C)

Applications of Sealing Face Masks

  • Pre-oxygenation
  • Bag-mask ventilation
  • Inhalational induction
  • Non-invasive ventilation (NIV)
  • Resuscitation

choices.text: By placing the flange at the level of the incisors and the tip at the angle of the mandible
By placing the flange at the angle of the mouth and the tip at the angle of the mandible
By placing the flange at the level of the incisors and the tip at the tragus of the ear
By placing the flange at the external nares and the tip at the tragus of the ear

questions.text: You are using a Guedel airway for a patient to improve the upper airway patency. How will you estimate the size you will require for the same?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A Guedel airway also known as an oropharyngeal airway, maintains upper airway patency by keeping the mouth open and preventing the tongue from falling backwards.
  • The airway is available in a range of sizes from neonate to adult.
  • To determine the correct size, the airway is held up to the patient's face. The size that is most appropriate for the patient can be estimated in two ways:
    • The "hard-to-hard" method, where the flange is placed at the level of the incisors and the tip at the angle of the mandible.
    • The "soft-to-soft" method, from the angle of the mouth to the tragus of the ear.
  • Always select the largest size that fits without resistance.
  • Confirm placement by observing chest rise and the absence of obstruction.

Flange at mouth angle (Option B) is too posterior, misaligns curvature.

Tip at the tragus but flange at incisors (Option C) overestimates length, risking pharyngeal trauma

Nares-to-tragus (Option D) applies to nasopharyngeal airways, not Guedel.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient is planned for left-sided fibro-adenoma excision of the breast. She is very anxious. She was given midazolam and fentanyl before induction of anaesthesia. The aims of premedication include
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Premedication before anaesthesia achieves anxiolysis (e.g., midazolam) and analgesia (e.g., fentanyl).
  • Midazolam provides anxiolysis, reducing patient stress and amnesia for induction.
  • Fentanyl delivers analgesia, blunting sympathetic response to airway manipulation.
  • Together they facilitate a smooth, cooperative induction, lower anaesthetic requirements, and reduce awareness risk.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female is planned for an emergency cesarean section for preeclampsia. She is planned for general anaesthesia under rapid sequence induction (RSI). Which of the following is a prerequisite for RSI?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pre-oxygenation is essential to extend the safe apnea period during RSI.

  • Pre-oxygenation: Administration of 100% O2 before induction of anaesthesia.
  • Mechanism: Replaces nitrogen in the functional residual capacity (FRC) with 100% O2
  • Advantages:
    • Increases O2 reserve, delaying desaturation during apnea
    • Elevates arterial PO2 for improved safety margin
  • Technique for RSI:
    • Administer 6 maximal vital-capacity breaths of 100% O2 over 60 seconds
    • Avoid bag-mask ventilation after loss of consciousness to minimise aspiration risk

Rapid Sequence Induction:

  • It is a specialised method of IV induction commonly used when an increased risk of gastric regurgitation and pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents exists.
  • Purpose: Minimize time between loss of consciousness and airway protection in high aspiration risk patients.
  • Key Steps:
    • Apply cricoid pressure
    • Administer induction agent immediately followed by succinylcholine (1–1.5 mg/kg IV)
    • Intubate without intermediate positive-pressure ventilation
  • Indications:
    • Full stomach or unknown fasting
    • Gastroesophageal reflux disease
    • Morbid obesity, diabetic gastroparesis
    • Pregnancy, trauma, or other high aspiration risk scenarios
  • Continuous waveform capnography confirms tracheal placement immediately after intubation.
  • Cricoid pressure should be released once the airway is secured.

 Explanation of other options:

  • Fasting (Option A) is ideal, but RSI is indicated when fasting status is unknown or inadequate.
  • Premedication (Option C) (antacids, metoclopramide) may be given, but is not a core RSI prerequisite.
  • Magnesium (Option D) has no role in the RSI protocol.

questions.text:
You are inducing a patient for general anaesthesia. After giving Propofol and Vecuronium, you do a laryngoscopy to see this view.

What is the Cormack-Lehane grade?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Cormack-Lehane grading system classifies the view of the glottis obtained during direct laryngoscopy into four grades based on how much of the vocal cords and epiglottis are visible.

In the image:

  • Only the posterior portion of the glottic opening (arytenoid cartilages and posterior commissure) is visible; the anterior glottis and full vocal cords are not seen.
  • Corresponds to CL grade II: partial glottic view with the anterior glottis not seen.

Cormack–Lehane classification:

  • Grade I: Entire vocal cords are visible. (Option A)
  • Grade II: Posterior part of the glottis is visible, anterior part is obscured.
  • Grade III: Only epiglottis is visible (Option C)
  • Grade IV: Neither epiglottis nor glottis is visible (Option D)

Grades III and IV are considered 'difficult.'

questions.text: You are asked to position a patient for general anaesthesia. The ideal position will be
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Atlanto-occipital extension and cervical flexion (the sniffing position) align the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes into a near straight line for a clear glottic view.
  • This axis alignment reduces the angle between the laryngoscope blade and vocal cords, improving first-pass intubation success.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female is planned for emergency cesarean section for preeclampsia. She is planned for general anaesthesia under rapid sequence induction. What is the manoeuvre being performed here?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cricoid pressure (Sellick's manoeuvre) digital pressure applied to the cricoid cartilage, pushing it posteriorly.
  • The oesophagus is compressed between the back of the cricoid ring and the cervical vertebrae.
  • The cricoid cartilage is used since it forms the only complete ring of the larynx and trachea.
  • Used to prevent passive regurgitation of gastric and oesophagal contents, during induction of anaesthesia.
  • Cricoid pressure is maintained until endotracheal tube cuff inflation confirms a secure airway.
  • Defined as part of Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI)
  • Key Steps of RSI:
    • Apply cricoid pressure (Sellick's manoeuvre)
    • Administer induction agent immediately followed by succinylcholine (1-1.5 mg/kg IV)
    • Intubate without intermediate positive-pressure ventilation
  • Manual in-line stabilization immobilizes the cervical spine, not occluding the esophagus. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: During intubation, the endo tracheal tube may become malpositioned in which of the following places?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All three sites have been reported as ETT malpositions, each compromising ventilation or airway protection in a distinct way.
  • Esophageal: Misplacement leads to failed ventilation and undetected esophageal intubation. (Option A)
  • Bronchus: Over-insertion often results in right main-stem bronchus intubation due to its more vertical angle. (Option B)
  • Laryngeal cuff position: Shallow placement leaves the cuff in the larynx, risking trauma and inadequate seal. (Option C)
  • Verify proper ETT position by capnography, auscultation, and chest rise.
  • Adjust depth to avoid right main-stem intubation or laryngeal cuff trauma.

questions.text: Patients requiring rapid sequence induction, OR those with high risk of aspiration are/is the following
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Induction, rapid sequence ('Crash induction'). Induction of anaesthesia in which risks of regurgitation and aspiration of gastric contents are minimized by:

  • Presence of a skilled assistant for sellicks maneuver, Suction equipment, emergency drugs and equipment
  • Regarding gastric tube - Aspiration of gastric tube if in place, before induction. Pre-induction passage of a stomach tube is rarely done routinely. A nasogastric tube is usually left in situ during induction.

choices.text: Increase in Paco2 from 35 to 40 mm Hg
Acute rise in venous pressure from coughing
100 mg IV succinylcholine in a patient in whom eye muscles have been detached from the globe

questions.text: Which of the following would NOT result in an increase in intraocular pressure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Elevation of PaCO2 out of the physiologic range (e.g., severe hypoventilation) will increase IOP, but small changes within normal limits (35 to 40 mm Hg) do not alter IOP.

  • In general, IV anesthetics (except ketamine), nondepolarizing neuromuscular blockers, inhaled anesthetics, narcotics, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, osmotic diuretics, and hypothermia decrease intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • Depolarizing neuromuscular blockers (succinylcholine) increase IOP whether given IM or IV. (Option B ruled out)
  • The succinylcholine-induced rise in IOP is due to drug-induced cycloplegia, not extraocular muscle contraction; it occurs even if the intraocular muscles are cut. (Option D ruled out)
  • The greatest IOP spikes (35-50 mm Hg) occur with coughing or vomiting via acute venous pressure increases. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text:
Anesthesia is induced in a 50-year-old, 125-kg man for anterior cervical fusion. The patient is placed on a ventilator. Peak airway pressure is noted to be 20 cm H2O with O2 saturation 99% on pulse oximeter. An hour later, the peak airway pressure rises to 40 cm H2O and PaCO2 is 38 mm Hg on the infrared spectrometer and on O2Â saturation falls to 88%. Blood pressure and heart rate are unchanged. The MOST likely cause of these findings is
One hour into ventilation of a 125 kg man post cervical fusion, peak airway pressure doubles to 40 cm H2O and SpO2 falls to 88%, with PaCO2 unchanged and hemodynamics stable. The most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mainstem(bronchial) intubation causes uneven lung ventilation - only one lung is ventilated.
  • Only the intubated lung receives tidal volume → resistance doubles → peak pressures rise.
  • Symptoms of a mainstem (bronchial) intubation include
    • Asymmetric chest expansion
    • Unilateral breath sounds
    • Elevation of peak airway pressures,
    • ABG abnormalities (hypoxemia).
  • The nonventilated lung gradually collapses, leading to atelectasis, hypoxemia, and pulmonary edema if uncorrected.
  • Hemodynamics stay stable since intrathoracic pressure and venous return are preserved.
  • Other factors that can elevate peak pressures
    • Airway obstruction (kinked tube, thick secretions, overinflated cuff) increases resistance in the circuit.
    • Bronchospasm narrows small airways via smooth-muscle contraction.
    • Excessive tidal volume delivers more gas than the lungs/compliance allow.
    • Chest wall rigidity (e.g., high-dose neuromuscular blockade failures or severe abdominal distension) reduces compliance.
    • Tension pneumothorax raises airway pressures but also causes hypotension and tachycardia from mediastinal shift.

Explanation of other options:

Pulmonary embolism (Option B) causes hypoxemia but no ↑ in peak airway pressures.

Tension pneumothorax (Option C)  elevates peak airway pressures but produces hypotension.

Venous air embolism (Option D) leads to hypotension and cardiovascular instability without ↑ in peak pressures.

questions.text: A number 6 endotracheal tube indicates which size?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Endotracheal tube sizes are designated by their internal diameter (ID), so a number 6  tube has a 6 mm lumen.
  • Tubes are manufactured in 0.5-mm ID increments (e.g., 6.0, 6.5, 7.0 mm).
  • Internal circumference is proportional to ID, but not the naming convention.
  • The glottic (distal) end is bevelled left-facing for smooth passage through the cords, with a Murphy's eye as a secondary vent if the main orifice is occluded.

Murphy's eye is an alternate opening for ventilation

  • Tube Types:
    • Uncuffed tubes: primarily for neonates and young children to reduce mucosal pressure.
    • Cuffed tubes:
      • Low-pressure, high-volume (cylindrical) cuffs for safe positive-pressure ventilation and aspiration prevention.
      • High-pressure, low-volume (round) cuffs (e.g., laser tubes) to resist combustion and gas mixing during speciality cases.
  • Optimal cuff pressure: 18-24 mm Hg (20-25 cm H2O).
  • Positioning: tip positioned ~3-4 cm above the carina; confirm with depth markings and auscultation.
